Description: Head bead of a ram. Large opaque white glass head of a ram in the round, glossy surface. Curved horns and ears formed of separate threads in dark-blue glass. Each eye a ball of dark blue outlined in opaque yellow. Yellow nostrils. Suspension loop in dark-blue glass. As with the human head beads, this bead was formed on a mandril over a red-brown core, certain indication of a Phoenician origin.
Curator's comments: As this object was once in the collection of Henry Wallis, it is probable that it was found in Egypt even though clearly made in Phoenicia. The amuletic value of the ram as a fertility symbol is well established in various cultures, but it is probable that this object was made for the export trade with Egypt.
Bibliographic references: Glass / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Glass in the British Museum (439)
Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (pl.46)
